chess.info: If you have decided to start this application, chances are, you know how to play chess.
Although if you don't, may the colors help you.
Select a movable piece to see where it can move (highlighted by green) or capture (red).
If you aren't sure which pieces can move, click an empty space.
The movable pieces will have a yellow highlight.
This also applies to every other mode out there, simply because it's convenient.
So if you are confused, you can always rely on it. (Probably.)
chess.cyclic.info: Same as regular chess, but the left and right edges are considered adjacent.
Everything else works as you'd expect - it's just the fact that the edges are connected.
chess.double.info: Same as regular chess, but you move twice each time.
Giving your opponent a check on your first turn of the two is not allowed.
chess.forced.info: The classical Forced Chess. For when you don't have time for regular chess.
The main differences are as follows:
1. Capturing is not optional anymore. You have to capture, even if it puts you in a bad position.
2. Pawns can only move one space ahead, not two.
3. Moves like castling and en passant are not allowed, simply because of the space limitations.
4. Pawns can't be promoted into knights or bishops.
chess.forced.modest.info: Same as Forced Chess, but you have to capture the least powerful piece if you have a choice.
Pawns are considered the least powerful piece, queens being the most powerful. Rooks are in between.
chess.forced.major.info: Same as Forced Chess, but every piece (except the kings) is a queen.
The sheer amount of power coming from the board is unexpectedly high.
chess.forced.minor.info: Same as Forced Chess, but every piece (except the kings) is a pawn.
Well, at least they can be promoted.
chess.forced.double.info: Same as Forced Chess, but you move twice each time.
Giving your opponent a check on your first turn of the two is not allowed, even if it is a capture.
chess.forced.cyclic.info: Forced Chess... on a cyclic board.
Just like in regular Cyclic Chess, the edges are connected.
chess.forced.modest.cyclic.info: Modest Forced Chess on a cyclic board.
chess.4x4.info: Ever wondered why does Forced Chess have that mandatory capturing rule? …no?
In any case, here's a variant of Forced Chess without the mandatory capturing rule.
chess.forced.sniper.info: In this variant, the board has 4 additional "towers" housing the 4 snipers.
Snipers look and capture like bishops, but don't move (even when capturing).
They can, however, check (and possibly even checkmate) the other king.
Capturing by a sniper is mandatory whenever possible, even when another capture is available.
(This also applies to Modest Sniper Forced Chess.)
A sniper can (and must) capture the other sniper once the diagonal is free.
The towers aren't there just for the snipers - kings (and queens) can also hide in there.
Oh, and pawns promote on the 3rd and 6th rows respectively and cannot promote into a sniper.
chess.forced.sniper.modest.info: Sniper Forced Chess. But modest. Sniper capturing is still mandatory.
chess.forced.reserve.info: In this variant, the board has an additional "reserve" with 8 knights.
These are just your normal everyday chess knights, and can step in and out of the central square.
Like in Sniper Chess, pawns promote on the 3rd and 6th rows respectively and can't promote into a knight.
chess.forced.reserve.modest.info: Nothing new to say about this one.
Like in regular chess, knights are considered more powerful than a pawn but less powerful than a rook.
chess.forced.reserve.pegasi.info: Knights have been replaced with invincible Pegasi in this one.
It's impossible to capture a Pegasus, no matter how hard you try.
chess.forced.sniper.reserve.pegasi.info: Everything you know and love, with an additional rule: snipers can capture Pegasi.
chess.forced.down.info: Any captured piece will respawn as a weaker piece on its starting position.
The order of respawning is as follows: Queen > Rook > Bishop > Knight > Pawn.
Pieces are unable to respawn if their starting position is taken by another piece.
Pawns can't respawn at all, but they can promote into a knight or a bishop.
Note that sometimes a capture can't be made because the respawned piece would check the king.
chess.forced.up.info: Any piece (except for the kings) gains experience points (XP) and can level up into a stronger piece.
The order of levelling is as follows: Pawn > Knight > Bishop > Rook > Queen > Amazon (i.e. Queen + Knight).
To level up, a pawn needs 4 XP, a knight needs 9, a bishop needs 16, a rook needs 25, and a queen needs 36 XP.
XP can be gained as follows:
- A non-capturing move with a check gives 2 XP.
- A capturing move gives XP depending on the captured piece:
Pawns give 3 XP, knights give 5, bishops give 7, rooks give 12, queens give 20, and amazons give 30 XP.
- If a check happened after a capturing move, it gives 2 extra XP.
- If a check happened after levelling up but not before levelling up, it is considered a check for XP calculations.
- If a check happened before levelling up but went away after levelling up, no XP will be taken away.
chess.forced.up.down.info: Here, pieces both level up and respawn. All earned XP resets after respawning.
This one got the name Forever Alone Forced Chess because of the sheer amount of work that's needed
to properly calculate everything and the difficulty of finding an actual partner for this variant.
chess.forced.up.res.info: In this variant, in addition to levelling up, the pieces can also gain resistance to other pieces.
If a piece has resistance to a certain piece type, then that piece type cannot capture said piece.
Each resistance level also grants resistance bonuses of all previous levels.
This also applies to kings. It's impossible to check (or checkmate) a king with a piece it has resistance to.
Resistance levels and the amounts of XP needed to get one are as follows:
chess.forced.up.res.pow.info: In this variant, in addition to levelling up and gaining resistance, the pieces can also upgrade their power.
If a piece has upgraded its power by 1, it can capture pieces that have resistance to its initial type.
Upgrading power by 2 grants the ability to capture pieces of the next resistance level, and so on.
The amounts of XP needed to upgrade power are as follows:
This sums up to a total of 251 XP, which should not be a problem for a true hardcore chess gamer.
chess.forced.up.down.res.info: Levelling up, respawning and resistance. Respawning drops resistance level by 1.
chess.forced.up.down.res.pow.info: Everything related to levels, plus respawning (which decreases both resistance level and power bonus by 1).
chess.forced.down.telefrag.info: Here, pieces are able to respawn even if their starting position is taken by another piece.
The piece that took the starting position would then respawn as well.
Capturing a piece on its starting position would respawn both pieces immediately.
The only exception is that pieces cannot respawn if their starting position is taken by a king.
chess.forced.up.down.telefrag.info: Both levelling up and forced respawning.
chess.forced.up.mob.info: Here pieces can level up by capturing mobs. Mobs cannot capture any piece and serve only as free XP.
They can move as a rook, bot only 1 square at a time. After each turn one of the mobs moves as follows:
1. All pieces except for the last moved piece are ignored by the mobs when determining a move.
2. If the last moved piece threatens to capture a single mob, that mob's moves are prioritized.
If it can, it moves back, otherwise to the nearest vertical edge, otherwise to the far edge, otherwise forward.
A square is considered to be threatened by the piece even if the piece can't move there due to being pinned.
If all possible squares are threatened, the mob still moves the same way.
3. If the piece is threatening several mobs at once, the mob that can get to a safe square is prioritized.
If there are several or none, the priority is determined by the files where mobs stand in order of c, d, b, a.
The first file with mobs is prioritized. If there are still several mobs of the file, the one that's closer
to the piece (or its initial position, if the distances to the piece are the same) is prioritized.
4. If the piece does not threaten to capture any mob, the moves are determined in the same manner
as long as the mob doesn't move on a dangerous square (unless there's no other choice).
Capturing a mob gives 10 XP. And yes, pawns can do the initial 2-square move and even capture en passant.
chess.forced.up.mob.armed.info: Here pieces can not only level up by capturing armed mobs, but also get damaged by their bullets.
Capturing an armed mob gives 15 XP. Armed mobs can't move, but can shoot with the following rules:
1. After every move, mobs shoot the piece that just moved, ignoring all others.
Each mob can shoot in the same way a queen moves. All mobs that can shoot the last moved piece will do so.
2. Pieces get the following damage per bullet:
It's very hard to get a knight, so knights don't take damage from bullets as an added bonus.
3. After the last mob gets captured, all mobs respawn on all free starting positions (8 or less).
Levelling up a piece does not bring back HP, it merely reduces the incoming damage.
chess.forced.up.down.res.mob.armed.info: Things you need to know about this variant of Forced Chess:
1. A knight is relatively common here, so knights aren't invincible. The initial damage per bullet is as follows:
2. Each turn bullet damage increases by 10% of the initial damage. By turn 11, the bullets are twice as powerful.
3. Resistance level also applies to armed mobs, reducing the damage from bullets:
LV1 - by 10 % (even from bullets on the same turn);
LV7 - by 100 % (the piece is completely bulletproof).
chess.forced.up.mob.armed.respawn.info: As you can probably guess from the name, mobs don't respawn in this variant.
Instead, each side's pieces respawn on the free starting positions
whenever a side has only a king (and all XP resets).
To compensate for this, mobs do more damage when there's less of them:
chess.forced.mountain.info: Here the board is bent into a mountain between the fourth and fifth ranks, though it's not obvious from above.
Every time both sides make 2 moves, all pieces slide in the direction of the nearest horizontal edge.
If a piece was standing on the first of eighth rank, it slides off the edge and into oblivion.
You still have to capture, but saving your king from sliding off the board is prioritized.
If it's impossible to save the king from sliding off, it's a checkmate if there's a check or a stalemate otherwise.
The pawns can always move up 2 spaces if they are moving away from the edge and don't cross the center.
Sliding to the promotion rank does not automatically promote a pawn.
chess.forced.mountains.info: A version of Mountain Forced Chess where pieces slide in parts instead of all at once.
After each side makes a move, pieces standing on one file slide in order of a -> b -> c -> d -> a (etc.)
chess.forced.cloning.info: Any piece except for the king will clone itself before making any non-capturing move.
The question of which of the two pieces actually makes the move will forever be left unanswered.
chess.forced.3d.info: Forced Chess 3D: a game for chess players who don't like to think in just two dimensions.
Diagonals in Forced Chess 3D are divided into 2 types: flat, which lie completely
in one of the planes, and spatial - going at a 45° angle to all planes.
Pawn - moves 1 square vertically, captures 1 square up (white) or down (black) on a flat diagonal.
Knight - moves and captures 2 squares in one direction and 1 square in another,
through four-dimensional space (by jumping "through" the pieces).
Bishop - moves and captures only on flat diagonals.
Cardinal - moves and captures both on flat and spatial diagonals.
Rook - moves and captures in parallel to any of the 3 cardinal directions.
Queen - moves and captures like a rook and a cardinal combined.
King - moves and captures like a queen, but only for 1 square.
chess.forced.3d.modest.info: Modest Forced Chess 3D. Notice that the rook is considered
more powerful than the bishop, but less powerful than the cardinal.
chess.4x4.cyclic.info: Chess but on a 4 by 4 cyclic board. Sure.
chess.4x4.double.info: Chess but on a 4 by 4 board, but you move twice each time. Sounds good.
chess.8x4.info: Chess but on a 8 by 4 board. We already had tall boards, now it's time for a wide board.
chess.cyclic.8x4.info: Chess but on a 8 by 4 cyclic board. Wide cylinder goes brrrrr.
chess.forced.8x4.info: Forced Chess but on a 8 by 4 board. So much movement potential, wasted on forced captures.
chess.forced.cyclic.8x4.info: Forced Chess but on a 8 by 4 cyclic board. I'm running out of things to say.
chess.forced.8x8.info: Forced Chess but on an 8 by 8 board-- wait, this is just chess with forced captures! How boring.
chess.forced.cyclic.8x8.info: Cyclic Forced Chess but on an 8 by 8 board. Just to spice things up.
chess.cyclic.8x12.info: Cyclic Chess but on an 8 by 12 board. Because why the heck not.
chess.cyclic.8x16.info: Cyclic Chess but on an 8 by 16 board. Yes please.
